ai.summary: Frith-Rathad na Hearadh is a demanding long-distance hike in the United Kingdom, spanning 75.3 km with a hard difficulty rating. The route combines varied terrain, remote sections, and several elevation changes, making pace and endurance key. It can be tackled as a multi-day trek or a strenuous day hike for experienced hikers who are well-prepared and self-sufficient.
ai.terrain_summary: Expect a mix of rough moorland, grassy trails, rocky outcrops, boggy sections, and occasional forest paths. The path quality varies from well-defined tracks to cross-country routes, with potential river crossings and long ascents and descents. Weather can be highly changeable in the UK, so conditions can impact footing and visibility on exposed ridges.
ai.safety_notes: - Distance and elevation demand thorough planning; consider multi-day trips with overnight stops. - Carry a detailed map and compass; GPS is helpful but do not rely on it exclusively. - Check local weather and daylight hours; expect rain, wind, and cold, even in summer. - Wear sturdy, ankle-supporting boots; bring extra socks and layers. - Stay on the route; in remote sections, navigation errors can lead to long detours. - Inform someone of your itinerary and expected return. - Pack a lightweight emergency kit (whistle, space blanket, first aid). - Carry enough food and water; plan for water sources and water treatment. - Be prepared for limited cell coverage in remote parts.
recommended_gear: Topographic map of the route and compass
Sturdy hiking boots with ankle support
Moisture-wicking base layers, insulating mid-layer, and a waterproof shell
Water bottles or hydration reservoir (minimum 2–3 L capacity)
High-energy food and snacks for the day(s)
First aid kit with blister care
Emergency whistle, bivy sack or space blanket
Dry bags or waterproof stuff sacks
Tent or bivouac gear (for multi-day trips)
Sleeping bag and sleeping mat (if camping)
Stove and fuel plus lighter/matches (if camping)
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly May to September) are best for visibility and drier conditions; winter months bring snow, shorter days, and harsher conditions.

seo.title: Frith-Rathad na Hearadh — 75.3 km Hard Hike in the UK
